column2: A hose can fill a water tank in 3 hours, but due to a small crack, it takes 4 hours to fill the tank. How much time will it take to empty the tank if it was full?
column13: To find the time it will take to completely empty the tank, we need to determine the rate at which the crack is causing the tank to empty. Let's denote the rate at which the hose can fill the tank as "F" (in units of tank volume per hour) and the rate at which the crack is causing the tank to empty as "E" (in units of tank volume per hour). From the given information, we know that the hose can fill the tank in 3 hours, so its filling rate is: F = 1 tank volume / 3 hours = 1/3 tank volume per hour Similarly, we know that the hose takes 4 hours to fill the tank due to the crack, so the combined rate of filling and emptying is: F - E = 1 tank volume / 4 hours = 1/4 tank volume per hour Now, we can set up an equation to find the crack's emptying rate: 1/3 - E = 1/4 To solve for E, we can rearrange the equation: E = 1/3 - 1/4 E = (4 - 3) / (3 * 4) E = 1 / 12 tank volume per hour Now that we know the crack's emptying rate, we can determine the time it will take to empty the tank completely. Since the crack is removing 1/12 of the tank volume every hour, it will take 12 hours to completely empty the entire tank. Therefore, it will take 12 hours to completely empty the tank if it was full.

column2: Pipe A and B can fill a tank in 30 minutes and 20 minutes respectively. Pipe C can empty the tank in 10 minutes. Pipe A and B are opened simultaneously and after 10 minutes pipe C is also opened. In what time will the tank be emptied after C is opened?
column13: Given information: Pipe A fills the tank in 30 minutes ⇒ its rate is 1/30 of the tank per minute Pipe B fills the tank in 20 minutes ⇒ its rate is 1/20 of the tank per minute Pipe C empties the tank in 10 minutes ⇒ its rate is -1/10 of the tank per minute (emptying) Step 1: Amount of water in the tank after first 10 minutes (only A and B open) Combined rate of A and B = 1/30 + 1/20 = 2/60 + 3/60 = 5/60 = 1/12 of the tank per minute In 10 minutes, amount filled = 10 × (1/12) = 10/12 = 5/6 of the tank So, when C is opened, the tank is 5/6 full. Step 2: Net rate when A, B, and C are all open Rate of A = 1/30 Rate of B = 1/20 Rate of C = -1/10 (emptying) Net rate = 1/30 + 1/20 - 1/10 = 2/60 + 3/60 - 6/60 = 5/60 - 6/60 = -1/60 of the tank per minute This means the tank is getting emptied at the rate of 1/60 of the tank per minute. Step 3: Time taken to empty the tank from 5/6 full Time = (Amount of water) ÷ (Rate of emptying) = (5/6) ÷ (1/60) = (5/6) × 60 = 5 × 10 = 50 minutes Therefore, the tank will be emptied in 50 minutes after pipe C is opened.

column2: Two workers A and B can complete a construction project in 10 days. If A takes 6 days longer than B to complete the project alone, how much time will it take for B to complete the project separately?
column13: Let the time taken by worker B to complete the project alone be b days. Then time taken by worker A to complete the project alone is (b + 6) days. Work rates: Rate of A = 1/(b + 6) projects per day Rate of B = 1/b projects per day Together they complete the project in 10 days, so their combined rate is 1/10 projects per day. Therefore: 1/(b + 6) + 1/b = 1/10 Combine the fractions: (b + (b + 6))/(b(b + 6)) = 1/10 (2b + 6)/(b(b + 6)) = 1/10 Cross-multiplying: 10(2b + 6) = b(b + 6) 20b + 60 = b² + 6b Rearranging: b² + 6b - 20b - 60 = 0 b² - 14b - 60 = 0 Solve the quadratic using the formula: b = [14 ± √(14² - 4×1×(-60))]/2 b = [14 ± √(196 + 240)]/2 b = [14 ± √436]/2 b = [14 ± 2√109]/2 b = 7 ± √109 Since time cannot be negative: b = 7 + √109 ≈ 7 + 10.44 = 17.44 days (approximately) Therefore, worker B will take approximately 17.44 days to complete the project separately.

column2: Two pumps P and Q can fill a swimming pool in 8 hours and 12 hours, respectively. Another pump R can empty the pool in 6 hours. Pumps P and Q are opened first, and then 2 hours later pump R is also opened. Find the time taken to fill the pool.
column13: Given information: Pump P can fill the pool in 8 hours ⇒ rate of P = 1/8 of the pool per hour Pump Q can fill the pool in 12 hours ⇒ rate of Q = 1/12 of the pool per hour Pump R can empty the pool in 6 hours ⇒ rate of R = -1/6 of the pool per hour (emptying) Step 1: Water filled in first 2 hours by P and Q only Combined rate of P and Q = 1/8 + 1/12 = 3/24 + 2/24 = 5/24 of the pool per hour In 2 hours, amount filled = 2 × (5/24) = 10/24 = 5/12 of the pool So, remaining part of the pool to be filled = 1 - 5/12 = 7/12 Step 2: After 2 hours, P, Q, and R are all opened Net rate = 1/8 + 1/12 - 1/6 = 3/24 + 2/24 - 4/24 = 1/24 of the pool per hour (net filling) Time to fill the remaining 7/12 of the pool: Time = (7/12) ÷ (1/24) = (7/12) × 24 = 14 hours Total time from the start: = 2 hours (first phase) + 14 hours (second phase) = 16 hours Therefore, the time taken to fill the pool is 16 hours.

column2: Two pumps A and B can fill a swimming pool in 20 hours and 30 hours, respectively. If both pumps are turned on simultaneously, after how much time should B be turned off so that the pool is filled in 18 hours?
column13: Given information: Pump A can fill the pool in 20 hours rate of A = 1/20 of the pool per hour Pump B can fill the pool in 30 hours rate of B = 1/30 of the pool per hour Let pump B be turned off after t hours. Pump A runs for the entire 18 hours. Water filled by A in 18 hours: = 18 × (1/20) = 18/20 = 9/10 of the pool Water filled by B in t hours: = t × (1/30) = t/30 of the pool Total water filled must be 1 (full pool): 9/10 + t/30 = 1 Solving for t: t/30 = 1 - 9/10 t/30 = 1/10 t = 30 × (1/10) t = 3 hours Therefore, pump B should be turned off after 3 hours.

column2: Two pumps can fill a swimming pool in 2 hours and 3 hours, respectively. However, due to a leakage, it takes an extra 20 minutes to fill the pool. How much time will the leakage take to empty the full pool?
column13: Step 1: Find the normal filling rate of the two pumps (without leakage) Pump 1 fills the pool in 2 hours ⇒ rate = 1/2 pool per hour Pump 2 fills the pool in 3 hours ⇒ rate = 1/3 pool per hour Combined rate of both pumps: 1/2 + 1/3 = 3/6 + 2/6 = 5/6 pool per hour Step 2: Calculate time without leakage Time = 1 ÷ (5/6) = 6/5 hours = 1.2 hours = 72 minutes Step 3: Calculate actual time with leakage Due to leakage, it takes 20 minutes extra, so: Actual time = 72 + 20 = 92 minutes Convert to hours: 92/60 = 46/30 = 23/15 hours Step 4: Find the leakage rate Let the leakage empty the full pool in L hours. Then leakage rate = 1/L pool per hour (emptying). Net rate with leakage: (1/2 + 1/3 - 1/L) = 1/(actual time) = 1 ÷ (23/15) = 15/23 pool per hour Therefore: 1/2 + 1/3 - 1/L = 15/23 5/6 - 1/L = 15/23 Step 5: Solve for L -1/L = 15/23 - 5/6 Compute RHS: 15/23 - 5/6 = (15×6 - 5×23)/(23×6) = (90 - 115)/138 = -25/138 So: -1/L = -25/138 1/L = 25/138 Therefore: L = 138/25 = 5.52 hours ≈ 5.5 hours The leakage will take approximately 5.5 hours to empty the full pool.

column2: Two pipes fill a tank in 15 and 20 minutes respectively, and a waste pipe can empty 2 gallons per minute. All three pipes working together can fill the tank in 10 minutes. What is the capacity of the tank?
column13: Let the capacity of the tank be V gallons. Given information: Pipe 1 fills the tank in 15 minutes ⇒ its rate = V/15 gallons per minute Pipe 2 fills the tank in 20 minutes ⇒ its rate = V/20 gallons per minute Waste pipe empties 2 gallons per minute ⇒ its rate = -2 gallons per minute (emptying) When all three are open together: Net rate = V/15 + V/20 - 2 gallons per minute Given that the tank is filled in 10 minutes with all three working: 10 × (V/15 + V/20 - 2) = V Solve for V: V/15 + V/20 = 4V/60 + 3V/60 = 7V/60 So: 10 × (7V/60 - 2) = V (70V/60) - 20 = V (7V/6) - 20 = V Bring V terms together: 7V/6 - V = 20 7V/6 - 6V/6 = 20 V/6 = 20 V = 120 Therefore, the capacity of the tank is 120 gallons.

column2: Two pipes A and B can fill a tank in 8 hours together. Both pipes are opened for 6 hours, and then pipe A is closed. The remaining part of the tank is filled by pipe B in 6 hours. How much time will pipe A take to fill the empty tank alone?
column13: Let the rates of pipes A and B be a and b tanks per hour respectively. Given that together they fill the tank in 8 hours: a + b = 1/8 ...(1) Step 1: Work done in first 6 hours by both A and B In 6 hours, amount of tank filled = 6(a + b) = 6 × (1/8) = 6/8 = 3/4 of the tank So, remaining part of the tank = 1 - 3/4 = 1/4 Step 2: Remaining 1/4 tank is filled by B alone in 6 hours So: 6b = 1/4 b = (1/4) ÷ 6 = 1/24 Step 3: Find a using equation (1) a + b = 1/8 a + 1/24 = 1/8 a = 1/8 - 1/24 a = 3/24 - 1/24 a = 2/24 a = 1/12 So, pipe A alone fills the full tank in: Time = 1 ÷ a = 1 ÷ (1/12) = 12 hours Therefore, pipe A will take 12 hours to fill the tank alone.

column2: The work efficiency of pipe B is 2 times that of pipe A, and the work efficiency of pipe C is 3 times that of pipe B. All three pipes can fill a cistern in 8 hours. Find the time taken by pipe A to fill the cistern alone.
column13: Let the work efficiency (rate) of pipe A be x cisterns per hour. Then: Pipe B's efficiency = 2x cisterns per hour (2 times A) Pipe C's efficiency = 3 × (2x) = 6x cisterns per hour (3 times B) Combined efficiency of A, B, and C together: x + 2x + 6x = 9x cisterns per hour Given that all three pipes together can fill the cistern in 8 hours: Their combined rate is 1/8 cistern per hour. So: 9x = 1/8 x = 1/(8 × 9) x = 1/72 Therefore, pipe A alone will take: Time = 1 ÷ (1/72) = 72 hours Hence, the time taken by pipe A to fill the cistern alone is 72 hours.

column2: There are four taps A, B, C, and D in a tank. They can fill the tank in 8 hours, 12 hours, 15 hours, and 20 hours respectively. At first, all of them are opened simultaneously. Then after 3 hours, tap C and D are closed and A and B are kept running. After the 6th hour, tap B is also closed. The remaining work is done by tap A alone. Find the percentage of the work done by tap A.
column13: Let the capacity of the tank be 1 (one full tank). Rates of filling per hour: Tap A fills the tank in 8 hours ⇒ rate of A = 1/8 Tap B fills the tank in 12 hours ⇒ rate of B = 1/12 Tap C fills the tank in 15 hours ⇒ rate of C = 1/15 Tap D fills the tank in 20 hours ⇒ rate of D = 1/20 Step 1: Work done in the first 3 hours (A, B, C, D all open) Combined rate of A, B, C, D: R_total = 1/8 + 1/12 + 1/15 + 1/20 Taking LCM of 8, 12, 15, 20 = 120: 1/8 = 15/120 1/12 = 10/120 1/15 = 8/120 1/20 = 6/120 R_total = (15 + 10 + 8 + 6)/120 = 39/120 = 13/40 In 3 hours, work done = 3 × (13/40) = 39/40 So after 3 hours, 39/40 of the tank is filled. Remaining work = 1 - 39/40 = 1/40 Step 2: Next phase with A and B only After 3 hours, only A and B are running. Rate of A and B together: R_AB = 1/8 + 1/12 Taking LCM of 8 and 12 = 24: 1/8 = 3/24 1/12 = 2/24 So, R_AB = 3/24 + 2/24 = 5/24 Let the extra time for A and B to finish the remaining 1/40 of the tank be t hours. Then: (5/24) × t = 1/40 t = (1/40) ÷ (5/24) = (1/40) × (24/5) = 24/200 = 3/25 hours So the tank is completely filled in: Total time = 3 + 3/25 = 75/25 + 3/25 = 78/25 hours = 3.12 hours Note: This means the tank gets full before the 6th hour, so the phase "after the 6th hour, B is closed and A alone works" actually never happens in reality. Step 3: Work done by tap A Tap A works from the beginning until the tank is full, i.e., for 3 + 3/25 = 78/25 hours. Work done by A = rate of A × time = (1/8) × (78/25) = 78/200 = 39/100 So tap A does 39/100 of the total work. Percentage of work done by tap A = (39/100) × 100 = 39%

column2: A large swimming pool can be filled by two pumps A and B in 45 minutes and 30 minutes respectively. How many minutes will it take to fill the swimming pool if B is used for half the time and A and B fill it together for the other half?
column13: Given information: Pump A can fill the pool in 45 minutes ⇒ rate of A = 1/45 pool per minute Pump B can fill the pool in 30 minutes ⇒ rate of B = 1/30 pool per minute Let the total time taken to fill the pool be T minutes. According to the question: For T/2 minutes, only pump B is used For the other T/2 minutes, both A and B are used together Work done by B alone in T/2 minutes: = (T/2) × (1/30) = T/60 Work done by A and B together in T/2 minutes: Rate of A + B = 1/45 + 1/30 = 2/90 + 3/90 = 5/90 = 1/18 pool per minute So, work done together in T/2 minutes: = (T/2) × (1/18) = T/36 Total work done = 1 full pool: T/60 + T/36 = 1 Taking LCM of 60 and 36 = 180: 3T/180 + 5T/180 = 1 8T/180 = 1 T = 180/8 T = 22.5 minutes Therefore, it will take 22.5 minutes to fill the swimming pool.
